upload_name: (Delete?) soc.005 Political Rights and Civil Liberties Index
public_title: Political Rights and Civil Liberties Index
metadata: [{'id': '59a427ac7b6c000012baa70b', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': '4c9190e9-205b-4ff8-83dd-ee08cd63a04c', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': '4c9190e9-205b-4ff8-83dd-ee08cd63a04c'}, 'language': 'en', 'name': 'Political Rights and Civil Liberties Index', 'description': 'Freedom in the World is Freedom House’s flagship annual report, assessing the condition of political rights and civil liberties around the world. It is composed of numerical ratings and supporting descriptive texts for 195 countries and 14 territories. Freedom in the World has been published since 1973, allowing Freedom House to track global trends in freedom over more than 40 years. External analysts assess the 209 countries and territories using a combination of on-the-ground research, consultations with local contacts, and information from news articles, nongovernmental organizations, governments, and a variety of other sources. Expert advisers and regional specialists then vet the analysts’ conclusions. The final product represents the consensus of the analysts, advisers, and Freedom House staff. For each country and territory, Freedom in the World analyzes the electoral process, political pluralism and participation, the functioning of the government, freedom of expression and of belief, associational and organizational rights, the rule of law, and personal autonomy and individual rights.', 'source': 'Freedom House', 'info': {'data_download_original_link': 'https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/freedom-world-2017', 'data_download_link': None, 'learn_more_link': 'https://freedomhouse.org/report-types/freedom-world', 'frequency_of_updates': 'Annual', 'date_of_content': '1972-2016', 'spatial_resolution': 'National', 'geographic_coverage': 'Global', 'license_link': 'TBD', 'license': 'TBD', 'citation': 'Freedom House. 2017. Freedom in the World. https://freedomhouse.org/report-types/freedom-world. upload_name: bio.001 Alliance for Zero Extinction Endangered Species Sites
(delete) ene.012 Percent of National Population with Access to Electricity
metadata: [{'id': '59a427a97b6c000012baa6ff', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': '46332f9b-30d6-4366-be24-582813256972', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': '46332f9b-30d6-4366-be24-582813256972'}, 'language': 'en', 'name': 'Access to Electricity', 'description': 'The access-to-electricity data are released through the Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) database and collected among different sources: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHSs) and Living Standards Measurement Surveys (LSMSs), Multi-indicator Cluster Surveys (MICSs), the World Health Survey (WHS), other nationally developed and implemented surveys, and various government agencies (e.g., ministries of energy and utilities). Given the low frequency and the regional distribution of some surveys, a number of countries have gaps in available data. To develop the historical evolution and starting point of electrification rates, a simple modeling approach was adopted to fill in the missing data points: around 1990, around 2000, and around 2010. Therefore, a country can have a continuum of 0 to 3 data points. There are 42 countries with 0 data points, and the weighted regional average was used as an estimate for electrification in each of the data periods. 170 countries have between 1 and 3 data points, and missing data are estimated by using a model with region, country, and time variables. The model keeps the original observation if data are available for any of the time periods. This modeling approach allowed the estimation of electrification rates for 212 countries over these 3 time periods (indicated as "Estimate"). The notation "Assumption" refers to the assumption of universal access in countries classified as developed by the United Nations.', 'source': 'SE4ALL/WBG/IEA/ESMAP', 'info': {'data_download_original_link': 'http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/EG.ELC.ACCS.ZS', 'data_download_link': 'https://wri-projects.s3.amazonaws.com/resourcewatch/ene_012_percentage_national_population_access_electricity.zip', 'learn_more_link': 'http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/EG.ELC.ACCS.ZS', 'frequency_of_updates': 'Annual (varies based on survey coverage)', 'date_of_content': '1990-2014', 'spatial_resolution': 'National', 'geographic_coverage': 'Global', 'license_link': 'http://data.worldbank.org/summary-terms-of-use', 'license': 'Open: You are free to copy, distribute, adapt, display, or include the data in other products for commercial and noncommercial purposes at no cost subject to the following limitations: You must include attribution for the data you use in the manner indicated in the metadata included with the data. You must not claim or imply that the World Bank endorses your use of the data or use the World Bank’s logo(s) or trademark(s) in conjunction with such use.', 'citation': 'World Bank. Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) database. [year.] "Access to Electricity, Urban (% of Urban Population)." http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/EG.ELC.ACCS.ZS. Accessed through Resource Watch, [date]. www.resourcewatch.org.', 'cautions': 'Given gaps in survey coverage, estimations have been made.', 'functions': 'An estimate of the percentage of the national population with access to electricity.', 'technical_title': 'Percent of National Population with Access to Electricity ', 'sources': [{'source-description': '', 'id': 0, 'source-name': 'Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL)'}, {'source-description': '', 'id': 1, 'source-name': 'World Bank Group (WBG)'}, {'source-description': '', 'id': 2, 'source-name': 'International Energy Agency (IEA)'}, {'source-description': '', 'id': 3, 'source-name': 'Energy Sector Management Assistance Program (ESMAP)'}], 'name': 'Access to Electricity', 'data_type': 'Tabular', 'rwId': 'ene.012', 'wri_rw_id': 'ene.012'}, 'createdAt': '2017-08-28T14:24:41.266Z', 'updatedAt': '2017-10-16T18:46:41.131Z', 'status': 'published'}}, {'id': '59e1252c0963b20010ce2e55', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': '46332f9b-30d6-4366-be24-582813256972', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': '46332f9b-30d6-4366-be24-582813256972'}, 'language': 'es', 'name': 'Access to Electricity', 'description': 'The access-to-electricity data are released through the Sustainable Energy for All (SE4ALL) database and collected among different sources: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHSs) and Living Standards Measurement Surveys (LSMSs), Multi-indicator Cluster Surveys (MICSs), the World Health Survey (WHS), other nationally developed and implemented surveys, and various government agencies (e.g., ministries of energy and utilities). Given the low frequency and the regional distribution of some surveys, a number of countries have gaps in available data. To develop the historical evolution and starting point of electrification rates, a simple modeling approach was adopted to fill in the missing data points: around 1990, around 2000, and around 2010. Therefore, a country can have a continuum of 0 to 3 data points. There are 42 countries with 0 data points, and the weighted regional average was used as an estimate for electrification in each of the data periods. 170 countries have between 1 and 3 data points, and missing data are estimated by using a model with region, country, and time variables. The model keeps the original observation if data are available for any of the time periods. This modeling approach allowed the estimation of electrification rates for 212 countries over these 3 time periods (indicated as "Estimate"). The notation "Assumption" refers to the assumption of universal access in countries classified as developed by the United Nations.', 'source': 'SE4ALL/WBG/IEA/ESMAP', 'info': {'data_download_original_link': 'http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/EG.ELC.ACCS.ZS', 'data_download_link': 'https://wri-projects.s3.amazonaws.com/resourcewatch/ene_012_percentage_national_population_access_electricity.zip', 'learn_more_link': 'http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/EG.ELC.ACCS.ZS', 'frequency_of_updates': 'Annual (varies based on survey coverage)', 'date_of_content': '1990-2014', 'spatial_resolution': 'National', 'geographic_coverage': 'Global', 'license_link': 'http://data.worldbank.org/summary-terms-of-use', 'license': 'Open: You are free to copy, distribute, adapt, display, or include the data in other products for commercial and noncommercial purposes at no cost subject to the following limitations: You must include attribution for the data you use in the manner indicated in the metadata included with the data. upload_name: (?) Open Air Quality: O3 (in Parts per million PPM).
(?) Open Air Quality: CO (in Parts per million).
(?) Open Air Quality: SO2 (in Parts per million).
metadata: [{'id': '59d538fef5f9fb00106512d9', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': '5abe1f7f-ccca-4119-887d-13b9d40b3c16', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': '5abe1f7f-ccca-4119-887d-13b9d40b3c16'}, 'language': 'en', 'name': 'Air Quality Measurements', 'description': 'OpenAQ is an open-source project to surface live, real-time air quality data from around the world. Its “mission is to enable previously impossible science, impact policy and empower the public to fight air pollution.” The data include air pollutant measurements for PM10, PM2.5, sulfur dioxide (SO2), carbon monoxide (CO), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), ozone (O3), and black carbon (BC), from over 5,400 locations in 48 countries as of June 2017. Scientists, researchers, developers, and citizens can use these data to understand how air quality in different locations changes over time.    OpenAQ has 5 criteria for including data sources in its platform:    1. Data must represent one of these pollutant types: PM10, PM2.5, SO2, CO, NO2, O3, or BC.    2. Data must be from an official-level stationary, outdoor air quality source, defined as data produced by a government entity or international organization.    3. Data must be "raw" and reported in physical concentrations on their originating site.    4. Data must be at the "station-level," not aggregated into a higher (e.g., city) level.    5. Data must be from measurements averaged between 10 minutes and 24 hours.    For more information on OpenAQ, see its article in Medium: https://medium.com/@openaq/where-does-openaq-data-come-from-a5cf9f3a5c85.    The most recent OpenAQ data are also available as a public data set on Google BigQuery: https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/public-data/openaq.', 'source': 'OpenAQ', 'info': {'download_from_source': 'null', 'download_data_s3': 'null', 'learn_more_link': 'https://openaq.org/', 'frequency_of_updates': 'Hourly', 'date_of_content': 'Varies by country and source', 'spatial_resolution': 'null', 'geographic_coverage': 'Argentina, Australia, Austria, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brazil, Canada, Chile, China, Colombia, Croatia, Czech Republic, Denmark, Ethiopia, Finland, France, Germany, Gibraltar, Hungary, India, Indonesia, Ireland, Israel, Kosovo, Kuwait, Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Mexico, Mongolia, Nepal, the Netherlands, Nigeria, Norway, Peru, the Philippines, Poland, Russian Federation, Singapore, Spain, Sweden, Taiwan (Province of China), Thailand, Turkey, Uganda, United Kingdom, United States, Vietnam', 'link_to_license': 'https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/', 'summary_of_license': 'No restrictions', 'citation': 'Hasenkopf, Christa A., David C. Adukpo, Michael Brauer, H. Langley Dewitt, Sarath Guttikunda, Alaa I. Ibrahim, Delgerzul Lodoisamba, et al. 2016. "To Combat Air Inequality, Governments and Researchers Must Open Their Data." Clean Air Journal = Tydskrif vir Skoon Lug 26 (2): 8-10. Accessed through Resource Watch, [date]. www.resourcewatch.org.', 'cautions': 'Data on the OpenAQ Application Programming Interface (API) are as reported by official entities. All quality control and data verification should be performed by users.', 'function': 'Record of official, stationary, outdoor air quality measurements reported by government entities or international organizations.', 'technical_title': 'OpenAQ Air Quality Concentrations: PM2.5, PM10, NO2, SO2, O3, CO, BC', 'source_organization': 'OpenAQ (OpenAQ)', 'name': 'Air Quality Measurements', 'data_type': 'Vector', 'wri_rw_id': 'cit.003'}, 'createdAt': '2017-10-04T19:39:42.308Z', 'updatedAt': '2017-10-06T15:05:27.387Z', 'status': 'published'}}]

metadata: [{'id': '59dd23f326cb7a0013147ab7', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': 'ddac9a5a-1b8a-4c04-b47e-70ef527addc1', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': 'ddac9a5a-1b8a-4c04-b47e-70ef527addc1'}, 'language': 'en', 'name': 'Land Tenure by Owner', 'description': 'The forest tenure tool from the Rights and Resources initiative (RRI) displays forest ownership data in 2002 and 2013. This quantitative approach monitors spatial forest tenure data---that is, who owns how many hectares of a given forest. RRI recognizes 4 categories of land ownership: (1) owned by indigenous peoples and local communities, (2) designated for indigenous peoples and local communities, (3) administered by governments, and (4) owned by individuals and private firms. This statutory forest data set currently covers 52 countries containing nearly 90 percent of the world’s forests. See more at http://rightsandresources.org/en/work-impact/tenure-data-tool/methodology/#.WSXpthPyvwc.', 'source': 'RRI', 'info': {'spatial_resolution': 'National', 'license_link': 'http://rightsandresources.org/en/work-impact/tenure-data-tool/#.WSXopBPyvwc', 'license': 'Creative Commons Attribution 4.0', 'frequency_of_updates': 'No known updates', 'date_of_content': '2002 and 2013', 'geographic_coverage': 'Select countries (52): Angola, Bhutan, Bolivia, Brazil, Cambodia, Cameroon, Central African Republic, China, Colombia, Costa Rica, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ethiopia, Gabon, the Gambia, Guyana, Honduras, India, Indonesia, Kenya, Lao PDR, Mexico, Myanmar, Nepal, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippines, Republic of the Congo, Suriname, Tanzania, Thailand, Togo, Vietnam, and Zambia. See more at http://rightsandresources.org/en/work-impact/tenure-data-tool/#sthash.LgYZpTwX.7sR4p1ms.dpuf.', 'cautions': 'All numbers are rounded to the nearest hundredth of a Mha.', 'functions': 'Statutory forest tenure change from 2002 to 2013 in 52 of the world’s most highly forested countries.', 'sources': [{'source-description': 'Rights and Resources Initiative (RRI)', 'id': 0, 'source-name': 'https://rightsandresources.org/en/#.WeDunxNSy8o'}], 'rwId': 'for.022', 'wri_rw_id': 'for.022', 'name': 'Land Tenure by Owner', 'technical_title': 'Tenure Data & Tool', 'data_download_link': 'https://wri-public-data.s3.amazonaws.com/resourcewatch/for.022_land_tenure_by_owner.zip', 'data_download_original_link': 'http://rightsandresources.org/en/work-impact/tenure-data-tool/#.Wcz7acjfo2y'}, 'columns': {}, 'createdAt': '2017-10-10T19:48:03.686Z', 'updatedAt': '2017-10-13T16:55:21.675Z', 'status': 'published'}}]

upload_name: (? what datatset) Land Surface Temperature Anomaly (8 DAY)
metadata: [{'id': '59e0dd665c3a600010570493', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': 'dcd1e9c7-1370-404e-8816-eaa51d4b1a39', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': 'dcd1e9c7-1370-404e-8816-eaa51d4b1a39'}, 'language': 'en', 'name': '', 'description': 'Land surface temperature is how hot or cold the ground feels to the touch. An anomaly is when something is different from average. These maps show where Earth’s surface was warmer or cooler in the daytime than the average temperatures for the same week or month from 2001-2010. So, a land surface temperature anomaly map for May 2002 shows how that month’s average temperature was different from the average temperature for all Mays between 2001 and 2010.', 'source': '', 'info': {'name': 'Land Surface temperature Anomaly', 'technical_title': 'Land Surface temperature anomaly'}, 'columns': {}, 'createdAt': '2017-10-13T15:36:06.656Z', 'updatedAt': '2017-10-13T15:47:28.528Z', 'status': 'published'}}]

upload_name: (delete) Watersheds at risk due to erosion
metadata: [{'id': '59a427a7ce86740012fcb22b', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': '5a8f3a76-0a61-4b24-a549-f109c34e4987', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': '5a8f3a76-0a61-4b24-a549-f109c34e4987'}, 'language': 'en', 'name': 'Erosion Risk', 'description': 'This global erosion layer, created by researchers at WRI, shows the risk of erosion around the world, from low to high, calculated from the Revised Universal Soil Loss Equation (RUSLE). This predicts annual soil loss from rainfall and runoff and is the most common model used at large spatial scales due to its relatively simple structure and empirical basis. The model takes into account rainfall erosivity, topography, soil erodibility, land cover and management, and conservation practices. Because the RUSLE model was developed based on agricultural plot scale and parameterized for environmental conditions in the United States, modifications of the methods and data inputs are necessary to make the equation applicable to the rest of the globe. The result of the global model was categorized into 5 quantiles, corresponding to low to high erosion risks.', 'source': 'WRI', 'info': {'data_download_original_link': None, 'data_download_link': None, 'learn_more_link': 'http://water.globalforestwatch.org/map/', 'frequency_of_updates': 'No known updates', 'date_of_content': '2015', 'spatial_resolution': '15 x 15 arc second', 'geographic_coverage': 'Global', 'license_link': 'http://water.globalforestwatch.org/map/', 'license': 'Creative Commons Attribution 4.0', 'citation': 'World Resources Institute. 2016. "Erosion." Global Forest Watch Water. Accessed through Resource Watch, [date]. www.resourcewatch.org.', 'cautions': "The RUSLE model was originally developed to be applicable on the agriculture plot scale and was parameterized for environmental conditions in the United States. The application of the model on a global scale may contain uncertainly and overestimation compared to available observed data, especially for tropical regions, polar climate zones, and high mountainous regions. Adjustments to the model (see below) have improved its global applicability, especially for mountainous regions, but they do not eliminate the model's bias and uncertainty. The accuracy of this layer has not been assessed. The model does not account for sediment deposition or sediment transport.", 'functions': 'Estimates of soil loss from rainfall and runoff.', 'technical_title': None, 'sources': [{'source-description': '', 'id': 0, 'source-name': 'World Resources Institute (WRI)'}], 'name': 'Erosion Risk', 'data_type': 'Raster', 'rwId': 'wat.015', 'wri_rw_id': 'wat.015'}, 'createdAt': '2017-08-28T14:24:39.351Z', 'updatedAt': '2017-10-12T19:40:53.751Z', 'status': 'published'}}]

[{'id': '58a310a83d81e10b00e6a5b9', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': '42de3f98-ba1c-4572-a227-2e18d45239a5', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': '42de3f98-ba1c-4572-a227-2e18d45239a5'}, 'language': 'es', 'name': 'State Fragility Index', 'description': "The state Fragility Index 1995-2015, provides annual state fragility, effectiveness, and legitimacy indices and the eight component indicators for the world's 167 countries with populations greater than 500,000 in 2015 (SPSS and Excel data files). Technical information on the sources and construction of the indices and indicators is provided with the State Fragility Matrix 2015 (above) and in Global Report 2014 (link on left)", 'source': 'http://gis.ncdc.noaa.gov/all-records/catalog/search/resource/details.page?id=gov.noaa.ncdc:C00532', 'citation': '', 'license': '', 'info': {'dataDownload': 'http://www.systemicpeace.org/inscrdata.html', 'organization': 'NOAA', 'source-long': 'Center for Systemic Peace (used in HCSS analysis)', 'short-description': "The state Fragility Index 1995-2015, provides annual state fragility, effectiveness, and legitimacy indices and the eight component indicators for the world's 167 countries with populations greater than 500,000 in 2015 (SPSS and Excel data files). Technical information on the sources and construction of the indices and indicators is provided with the State Fragility Matrix 2015 (above) and in Global Report 2014 (link on left)", 'spatial-coverage': 'Global', 'spatial-resolution': 'National', 'temporal-coverage': '1995-2015', 'temporal-resolution': '2015', 'subtitle': 'Drivers of Vulnerability: State Fragility Index, Hague Center for Strategic Studies.'}, 'createdAt': '2017-02-14T14:14:00.308Z', 'updatedAt': '2017-02-14T14:14:00.308Z', 'status': 'published'}}]

[{'id': '5936a645c155fe000bbad729', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': '5903f1d7-2240-4591-b970-33b32fe3be54', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': '5903f1d7-2240-4591-b970-33b32fe3be54'}, 'language': 'en', 'name': 'Baseline Water Stress', 'description': 'Baseline Water Stress is part of the Aqueduct Risk Framework created by WRI for measuring and mapping water risk around the world. WRI built Aqueduct to help companies, investors, governments, and communities better understand where and how water risks are emerging worldwide. Baseline water stress values are a physical risk quantity calculation. Available blue water is an estimate of surface water availability minus upstream consumptive use.    Baseline water stress is the total annual water withdrawals (total amount of water removed from freshwater sources for human use) expressed as a percentage of the total annual available flow (accumulated runoff upstream of the catchment plus the runoff in the catchment). Higher values indicate more competition among users.     Water supply is computed from runoff (R), the water available to flow across the landscape from a particular location, and is calculated as the remainder of precipitation (P) after evapotranspiration (ET) and change in soil moisture storage (∆S) are accounted for (i.e., R = P – ET – ∆S). The runoff data are courtesy of NASA Goddard Earth Sciences Data and Information Services Center’s Global Land Data Assimilation System Version 2 NOAH v. 3.3 land surface model for the years 1950 to 2010.    Arid areas are scored as high stress when calculating aggregated scores. The water withdrawals were divided by the mean available blue water from 1950 to 2010 globally. Areas with available blue water and water withdrawal less than 0.03 and 0.012 m/m2 respectively are coded as “arid and low water use.” For additional information, please see http://www.wri.org/sites/default/files/Aqueduct_Global_Maps_2.1.pdf.', 'source': 'WRI', 'info': {'download_from_source': 'null', 'download_data_s3': 'null', 'data_download_link': ['null', 'null'], 'learn_more_link': 'http://www.wri.org/sites/default/files/Aqueduct_Global_Maps_2.1.pdf', 'frequency_of_updates': 'No known updates', 'date_of_content': '2014', 'spatial_resolution': 'null', 'geographic_coverage': 'Global', 'link_to_license': 'https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/', 'summary_of_license': 'Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 License', 'citation': 'Gassert, F., M. Landis, M. Luck, P. Reig, and T. Shiao. 2014. “Aqueduct Global Maps 2.1.” Working Paper. Washington, DC: World Resources Institute. Available online at http://www.wri.org/publication/aqueduct-global-maps-21. Accessed through Resource Watch, [date]. www.resourcewatch.org.', 'cautions': 'These numbers are all calculations and may contain inaccuracies. It is difficult to ensure that all water withdrawals are included in measurements. WRI cautions that working papers contain preliminary research, analysis, findings, and recommendations.', 'function': 'Total annual water withdrawals as a percent of total annual available flow.', 'technical_title': 'Aqueduct Baseline Water Stress', 'source_organization': 'World Resources Institute (WRI)', 'name': 'Baseline Water Stress', 'data_type': 'Vector', 'wri_rw_id': 'wat.001'}, 'createdAt': '2017-06-06T12:55:33.153Z', 'updatedAt': '2017-10-06T15:34:20.074Z', 'status': 'published'}}]

metadata: [{'id': '59a426727b6c000012baa6f9', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': '415dd499-8385-4c23-bd18-8ac49803cf9e', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': '415dd499-8385-4c23-bd18-8ac49803cf9e'}, 'language': 'en', 'name': 'Land Water Content', 'description': 'The Global Land Data Assimilation System (GLDAS) collects and prepares satellite and ground-based observation data products for use in Land Surface Models (LSMs). These data are a result of forcing the National Centers for Environmental Prediction / Oregon State University / Air Force / Hydrologic Research Lab (NOAH) LSM. The GLDAS is developed and distributed by NASA and the Goddard Earth Sciences Data and Information Services Center (GES DISC). GLDAS 2.1 data are available in 3-hour and monthly increments, covering the years from 2000 to near-present.    This selection of GLDAS contains data on the amount of water stored as root-level soil moisture. The GLDAS incorporates satellite data on vegetation derived from the Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR), soil parameter maps, and topographic maps.    **CONSULT EXPERTS TO FINISH** , https://hydro1.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/data/GLDAS/GLDAS_NOAH025_3H.2.0/doc/README_GLDAS2.pdf', 'source': 'NASA/NASA GSFC/NOAA CPC', 'info': {'download_from_source': 'null', 'download_data_s3': 'null', 'learn_more_link': 'https://disc.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov/services/grads-gds/gldas, https://disc.gsfc.nasa.gov/uui/datasets/GLDAS_CLM10SUBP_3H_V001/summary?keywords=precipitation%20gldas&start=1920-01-01&end=2017-03-24#documentation,  http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/pdf/10.1175/BAMS-85-3-381, https://grace.jpl.nasa.gov/data/get-data/land-water-content/#citation', 'frequency_of_updates': 'Monthly', 'date_of_content': '2000 to near-present', 'spatial_resolution': '0.25 degree', 'geographic_coverage': 'Global', 'link_to_license': 'https://wiki.creativecommons.org/wiki/Public_domain', 'summary_of_license': 'Public domain', 'citation': 'Rodell, M., P.R. Houser, U. Jambor, J. Gottschalck, K. Mitchell, C.-J. Meng, K. Arsenault, B. Cosgrove, J. Radakovich, M. Bosilovich, J.K. Entin, J.P. Walker, D. Lohmann, and D. Toll. 2004. "The Global Land Data Assimilation System." Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society 85(3): 381-394. Data available from https://mirador.gsfc.nasa.gov/cgi-bin/mirador/collectionlist.pl?search=1&page=1&keyword=gldas&startTime=&endTime=&location=&submit=Search+GES-DISC&event=. Accessed through Resource Watch, [date]. www.resourcewatch.org.', 'cautions': 'Does not include groundwater and separate surface water components. Does not include a dynamic ice model, and due to this the Greenland ice sheet areas do not have any data.', 'function': 'High-resolution estimates of water and energy stored on land surfaces. These data are useful for adjusting atmospheric and climate models for making improved forecasts.', 'technical_title': 'null', 'source_organization': 'National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA)/National Aeronautics and Space Administration Goddard Space Flight Centre (NASA GSFC)/National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Center for Weather and Climate Prediction (NOAA CPC)', 'name': 'Land Water Content', 'data_type': 'Raster', 'wri_rw_id': 'foo.002'}, 'createdAt': '2017-08-28T14:19:30.380Z', 'updatedAt': '2017-10-04T20:26:14.422Z', 'status': 'published'}}]

[{'id': '59a427aace86740012fcb238', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': 'bd3ad33a-886b-4456-a032-119b9ac064de', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': 'bd3ad33a-886b-4456-a032-119b9ac064de'}, 'language': 'en', 'name': 'Actual and Potential Crop Yields', 'description': "Global Yield Gap Atlas Crop Yield Gap (GYGA-Yg) data compare the performance of crop yields in a location to the theoretically potential yields with no water stress (Yp) and potential yields in presence of some water stress (Yw). Yp and Yw are determined by the biophysical characteristics of the location and the needs of each crop type. This information can be used to identify high- and low-performing crop-growing regions, and to motivate technology and expertise transfer to address suboptimal yields. GYGA-Yg data provide a new perspective in the field of crop yield gap analysis, as they move beyond using gridded climate data to incorporate locally observed climate and production data as much as possible.    The smallest unit of analysis for the GYGA-Yg is the region around a reference weather station (RWS). Each RWS is surrounded by a 100-km radius circular buffer. These buffers are then intersected with GYGA climate zones (GYGA-CZs), soil types, and cropping system information. These factors are used as inputs to a crop model to estimate Yw and/or Yp for each RWS buffer zone.    GYGA-CZs are defined by growing degree days (GDDs), temperature seasonality, and an annual aridity index (AI), all of which are measured on a 5 arc minute grid. GDDs are defined as the number of days that the mean temperature is above 0°C. Temperature seasonality is calculated to be the standard deviation of the 12 mean monthly temperatures. AI is the ratio of mean annual precipitation over mean annual evapotranspiration.     Cropping system information includes the amount of harvested area, the cropping intensity of growth, and aspects of management such as use of irrigation, planting date, and development timeline of various crops.    Yield gaps are calculated as the difference between Yw/Yp (simulated yield potential with and without water stress, respectively) and on-farm yields (Ya). Ya are taken from recent national crop-specific yield statistics at the finest resolution available. Ideally, this is at a scale smaller than the GYGA-CZ clipped RWS buffer areas. If national statistics are not available, household surveys that ask about crop production may be used, such as are collected by groups like the World Bank and the Consultative Group for International Agricultural Research (CGIAR). If these are not available, then GYGA country agronomist experts' estimates are used. If there are insufficiently detailed estimates available from country experts, the last resort is to use country-level production statistics.", 'source': 'GYGA', 'info': {'data_download_link': 'null', 'frequency_of_updates': 'Annual', 'date_of_content': '2012-present', 'spatial_resolution': '100 km radius circles centered on RWS, potentially clipped by climate zone boundaries', 'geographic_coverage': 'Global', 'link_to_linense': 'https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/', 'license': 'No restrictions', 'citation': 'Global Yield Gap and Water Productivity Atlas. 2017. www.yieldgap.org. Accessed through Resource Watch, [date]. www.resourcewatch.org.', 'cautions': 'The GYGA study uses varying resolutions of actual crop yield data. Some countries have detailed subnational statistics on yields, while others do not. A description of the method used to evaluate actual yield for each RWS is provided with the data. See the actual yield estimation methodology for more details: http://www.yieldgap.org/web/guest/methods-actual-yield.', 'learn_more_link': 'http://www.yieldgap.org/web/guest/yieldgaps', 'source_organization_link': 'null', 'source_organization': 'Global Yield Gap Atlas (GYGA)', 'function': 'Estimate the yield gap for major food crops in all major producing countries based on locally observed data.', 'functions': 'Estimate the yield gap for major food crops in all major producing countries based on locally observed data.', 'name': 'Actual and Potential Crop Yields', 'technical_title': 'Global Yield Gap Atlas, Irrigated and Rain-Fed Yield Gaps'}, 'createdAt': '2017-08-28T14:24:42.089Z', 'updatedAt': '2017-08-28T14:30:24.289Z', 'status': 'published'}}]

(delete) Global Distribution of Infant Mortality- Proxy for Poverty (SEDAC)
metadata: [{'id': '59a427ab7b6c000012baa706', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': 'ab806854-3c33-4008-a38d-a2bc71a8fc2c', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': 'ab806854-3c33-4008-a38d-a2bc71a8fc2c'}, 'language': 'en', 'name': 'Distribution of Infant Mortality', 'description': "The Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center and the Center for International Earth Science Information Network created the Global Distribution of Infant Mortality maps as part of their Gridded Poverty Mapping project. This data set is also known as Global Infant Mortality Rates. IMRs are a useful proxy for overall poverty levels because they are highly correlated with metrics such as income, education levels, and health status of the population. IMRs are particularly good for distinguishing poverty levels at low income levels. IMRs are reported as the rate of children who die before reaching 1 year old for every 1,000 live births.    Sources of data for the Global IMR map include Demographic and Health Surveys (39 countries), Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (5 countries), National Human Development Reports (14 countries), and National Statistical Offices (18 countries).    115 countries had national-level data only, from the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). 36 countries had no data. Brazil and Mexico had data for a total of 5,372 administrative units. 74 other countries had subnational data, with an average of 22 units per country.    Subnational IMR values were adjusted to be consistent with national UNICEF 2000 IMR values. These data are available as a spatial grid, downsampled using a proportional allocation algorithm.    A presentation detailing IMR data sources and related methods is available here: http://www.efgs.info/wp-content/uploads/conferences/efgs/2010/17_construction-of-Gridded-population-and-poverty-data-sets-from-different-data-sources-_Alex-de-Sherbinin.pdf.", 'source': 'NASA SEDAC/CIESIN', 'info': {'data_download_original_link': 'http://sedac.ciesin.columbia.edu/data/set/povmap-global-subnational-infant-mortality-rates/data-download', 'data_download_link': 'https://wri-public-data.s3.amazonaws.com/resourcewatch/soc_003_infant_mortality.zip', 'learn_more_link': 'http://sedac.ciesin.columbia.edu/data/set/povmap-global-subnational-infant-mortality-rates', 'frequency_of_updates': 'No updates planned', 'date_of_content': '2000', 'spatial_resolution': 'Subnational', 'geographic_coverage': 'Global', 'link_to_license': 'http://sedac.ciesin.columbia.edu/citations', 'summary_of_license': 'Citation required, noncommercial use only (see readme distributed with data).', 'citation': 'Center for International Earth Science Information Network (CIESIN), Columbia University. 2005. Poverty Mapping Project: Global Subnational Infant Mortality Rates. Palisades, NY: NASA Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (SEDAC). http://dx.doi.org/10.7927/H4PZ56R2. Accessed [DAY MONTH YEAR]. Accessed through Resource Watch, [date]. www.resourcewatch.org.', 'cautions': 'The data underlying these infant mortality rate estimates are based on survey results, which may not be truly representative of the administrative regions they are ascribed to.    These data are now quite outdated (over 17 years old), but they constitute one of the only recognized subnational data sets for global infant mortality rates.', 'function': 'Global subnational map of infant mortality rate estimates for the year 2000.', 'technical_title': 'Global Distribution of Infant Mortality', 'source_organization': 'National Aeronautics and Space Administration Socioeconomic Data and Applications Center (NASA SEDAC)/Columbia University Earth Institute Center for International Earth Science Information Network (CIESIN)', 'name': 'Distribution of Infant Mortality', 'data_type': 'Vector', 'wri_rw_id': 'soc.003'}, 'createdAt': '2017-08-28T14:24:43.342Z', 'updatedAt': '2017-10-10T20:14:58.537Z', 'status': 'published'}}]

[{'id': '59a427ac7b6c000012baa70a', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': '3973a9b5-4ee7-44a9-aaba-24e6a4f23358', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': '3973a9b5-4ee7-44a9-aaba-24e6a4f23358'}, 'language': 'en', 'name': 'Gross Domestic Product  (PPP, Current US$)', 'description': "The World Bank releases data on a country's gross domestic product converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates (PPP GDP). An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as the U.S. dollar has in the United States. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current international dollars. For most economies, PPP figures are extrapolated from the 2011 International Comparison Program benchmark estimates or imputed using a statistical model based on the 2011 ICP. For 47 high- and upper-middle-income economies, conversion factors are provided by Eurostat and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development.", 'source': 'WBG ICP', 'info': {'download_from_source': 'https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NY.GDP.MKTP.PP.CD', 'download_data_s3': 'https://wri-public-data.s3.amazonaws.com/resourcewatch/com_010_gdp_ppp_usd.zip', 'data_download_link': ['https://wri-public-data.s3.amazonaws.com/resourcewatch/com_010_gdp_ppp_usd.zip', 'https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NY.GDP.MKTP.PP.CD'], 'learn_more_link': 'http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NY.GDP.MKTP.PP.CD', 'frequency_of_updates': 'Annual', 'date_of_content': '1990-2015', 'spatial_resolution': 'National', 'geographic_coverage': 'Global', 'link_to_license': 'http://data.worldbank.org/summary-terms-of-use', 'summary_of_license': 'No restrictions, citation required', 'citation': 'World Bank. 2017. "Per Capita GDP, PPP, Current International $ (1990-2015)." Retrieved from http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NY.GDP.PCAP.PP.CD. Accessed through Resource Watch, [date]. www.resourcewatch.org.', 'cautions': 'For a complete description on calculations, please see http://www.worldbank.org/en/programs/icp.', 'function': 'Sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products.', 'technical_title': 'Gross domestic product (GDP), purchasing power parity (PPP) (current international $)', 'source_organization': 'World Bank Group International Comparison Program (WBG ICP)', 'name': 'Gross Domestic Product  (PPP, Current US$)', 'data_type': 'Tabular', 'wri_rw_id': 'com.010'}, 'createdAt': '2017-08-28T14:24:44.715Z', 'updatedAt': '2017-10-06T15:34:11.250Z', 'status': 'published'}}]

[{'id': '59a427a7ce86740012fcb22c', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': '9a74e4c4-33b5-46d8-90d0-ea0615b1620f', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': '9a74e4c4-33b5-46d8-90d0-ea0615b1620f'}, 'language': 'en', 'name': 'Gender Development Index', 'description': 'This data set of the Gender Development Index (GDI), released by the World Bank, measures gender gaps in human development achievements by accounting for disparities between women and men in 3 basic dimensions of human development using the same component indicators as in the Human Development Index (HDI). The HDI is a summary measure of average achievement in key dimensions of human development: a long and healthy life, being knowledgeable, and a decent standard of living. The HDI is the geometric mean of normalized indices for each of the 3 dimensions. The health dimension is assessed by life expectancy at birth; the education dimension is measured by mean of years of schooling for adults aged 25 years and more and expected years of schooling for children of school-entering age. The standard of living dimension is measured by gross national income per capita. The HDI uses the logarithm of income to reflect the diminishing importance of income with increasing gross national income (GNI). The scores for the 3 HDI dimension indices are then aggregated into a composite index using geometric mean. The GDI is the ratio of the HDIs calculated separately for females and males using the same methodology as in the HDI. It is a direct measure of gender gap, showing the female HDI as a percentage of the male HDI. The GDI is calculated for 161 countries and shows how much women are lagging behind their male counterparts in each dimension of human development. It facilitates understanding of the real gender gap in human development achievements and is useful in designing policy tools to close the gap. For additional information, please see http://hdr.undp.org/en/content/gender-development-index-gdi.', 'source': 'UNDP', 'info': {'data_download_original_link': 'http://hdr.undp.org/en/composite/GDI', 'data_download_link': 'https://wri-public-data.s3.amazonaws.com/resourcewatch/soc_002_gender_development_index.zip', 'learn_more_link': 'http://hdr.undp.org/en/content/gender-development-index-gdi', 'frequency_of_updates': 'annual', 'date_of_content': '1980-present', 'spatial_resolution': 'National', 'geographic_coverage': 'Global (160 countries)', 'link_to_license': 'http://hdr.undp.org/en/content/copyright-and-terms-use', 'summary_of_license': 'Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 IGO', 'citation': 'United Nations Development Programme, Human Development Report [year]. "Gender Development Index." Retrieved from http://hdr.undp.org/en/content/gender-development-index-gdi. Accessed through Resource Watch, [date]. www.resourcewatch.org.', 'cautions': 'The HDI/GDI simplifies and captures only part of what human development entails. It does not reflect on inequalities, poverty, human security, empowerment, etc.', 'function': 'National statistics on gender gaps in human development.', 'technical_title': None, 'source_organization': 'United Nations Development Programme (UNDP)', 'name': 'Gender Development Index', 'data_type': 'Tabular', 'wri_rw_id': 'soc.002'}, 'createdAt': '2017-08-28T14:24:39.456Z', 'updatedAt': '2017-10-10T20:14:58.320Z', 'status': 'published'}}]

public_title: Effect of Agricultural Policies on Commodity Prices
metadata: [{'id': '59a427ac7b6c000012baa708', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': '621a7e5e-20ca-4567-bf31-7c70dfd0b222', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': '621a7e5e-20ca-4567-bf31-7c70dfd0b222'}, 'language': 'en', 'name': 'Effect of Agricultural Policies on Commodity Prices', 'description': 'The Nominal Rate of Protection, released by the AgIncentives partnership led by IFPRI, measures the extent to which a set of agricultural policies affects the market price of a commodity. It is computed as the price difference, expressed as a percentage, between the farm gate price received by producers and an undistorted reference price at the farm gate level, or the price a farmer receives versus the price a farmer would receive without these policies in place. The purpose of this indicator is not to provide a holistic measurement of various agricultural policies, in contrast with the Producer Support Estimate or the Nominal Rate of Assistance. It focuses only on the price implications of policies and will be larger for countries using price interventions compared to countries using farm subsidies.', 'source': 'AgIncentives/IFPRI', 'info': {'data_download_original_link': 'http://www.ag-incentives.org/indicator/nominal-rate-protection', 'data_download_link': 'https://wri-public-data.s3.amazonaws.com/resourcewatch/com_028_effect_of_ag_prices_on_commodity_prices.zip', 'learn_more_link': 'http://www.ag-incentives.org/indicator/nominal-rate-protection', 'frequency_of_updates': 'Annual', 'date_of_content': '2005-2015', 'spatial_resolution': 'National', 'geographic_coverage': '57 countries', 'link_to_license': 'https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/3.0/', 'summary_of_license': 'Attribution-NonCommercial 3.0 Unported', 'citation': 'AgIncentives/International Food Policy Research Group (IFPRI). 2015. "Nominal Rate of Protection." http://www.ag-incentives.org/indicator/nominal-rate-protection. Accessed through Resource Watch, [date]. www.resourcewatch.org.', 'cautions': 'Product and country coverage of an aggregate may vary over time due to changes in data availability.', 'function': 'The Nominal Rate of Protection measures the extent to which a set of agricultural policies affects the market price of a commodity.', 'technical_title': 'Nominal Rate of Protection (NRP)', 'source_organization': 'AgIncentives (AgIncentives)/International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI)', 'name': 'Effect of Agricultural Policies on Commodity Prices', 'data_type': 'Tabular', 'wri_rw_id': 'com.028'}, 'createdAt': '2017-08-28T14:24:44.530Z', 'updatedAt': '2017-10-10T20:14:50.131Z', 'status': 'published'}}]

upload_name: (delete?) GDP per capita, PPP (current international $) (World Bank)
metadata: [{'id': '59a427ac7b6c000012baa709', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': '995c82b4-6fd0-44de-b21c-20fdce9738d9', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': '995c82b4-6fd0-44de-b21c-20fdce9738d9'}, 'language': 'en', 'name': 'Annual Precipitation', 'description': "The World Bank releases a GDP per capita based on purchasing power parity. PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as the U.S. dollar has in the United States. GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current international dollars based on the 2011 International Comparison Program round.", 'source': 'UC Berkeley', 'info': {'data_download_original_link': None, 'data_download_link': None, 'technical_title': None, 'name': 'Annual Precipitation ', 'wri_rw_id': 'wat.034'}, 'createdAt': '2017-08-28T14:24:44.615Z', 'updatedAt': '2017-10-10T21:17:49.535Z', 'status': 'published'}}]

[{'id': '59a427aace86740012fcb239', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': '426fa4e2-edee-4f54-93d1-af95d7f4aec8', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': '426fa4e2-edee-4f54-93d1-af95d7f4aec8'}, 'language': 'en', 'name': 'Multidimentional Poverty Index', 'description': "The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) compiles the Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) as part of its Human Development Report initiative. The MPI is calculated for 102 countries at the household level and summarizes information on multiple deprivations into a single number. These measures can be unpacked to show the composition of poverty both across countries, regions, and the world and within countries by ethnic group, urban/rural location, as well as other key household and community characteristics.    Indicators shown in the MPI include the following:    Health: Nutrition, Child mortality  Education: Years of schooling, Children enrolled  Standard of living: Cooking fuel, Toilet, Water, Electricity, Floor, Assets    The MPI is calculated by multiplying the incidence of poverty by the intensity of poverty. The incidence of poverty is the proportion of people considered to experience multidimensional poverty, i.e., that are considered deprived in at least one third of the MPI's weighted indicators. The intensity of multidimensional poverty is the weighted average number of deprivations poor people experience at the same time.     The main data sources of the MPI are the Macro Demographic and Health Survey (DHS) of the Inner City Fund (ICF) and the Multiple Indicators Cluster Survey (MICS) of the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF). These databases are publicly available and comparable for most developing countries. They are supplemented by similar databases for select nations. A full list of these data sources is available through the MPI FAQs: http://hdr.undp.org/en/faq-page/multidimensional-poverty-index-mpi.", 'source': 'UNDP/OPHI', 'info': {'data_download_original_link': 'http://hdr.undp.org/en/data#', 'data_download_link': 'https://wri-public-data.s3.amazonaws.com/resourcewatch/soc_006_multidimensional_poverty_index.zip', 'learn_more_link': 'http://hdr.undp.org/en/content/multidimensional-poverty-index-mpi', 'frequency_of_updates': 'Yearly', 'date_of_content': '2010-present', 'spatial_resolution': 'National', 'geographic_coverage': '102 countries', 'link_to_license': 'https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/igo/legalcode', 'summary_of_license': 'Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 IGO', 'citation': 'Alkire, Sabina, and Maria Emma Santos. 2010. "Acute Multidimensional Poverty: A New Index for Developing Countries." Accessed through Resource Watch, [date]. www.resourcewatch.org.', 'cautions': 'The methodology the UNDP used to calculate the MPI changed in 2014. The changes followed a series of conferences on measuring human progress and are intended to align the MPI more with the Millennium Development Goals. The OPHI continues to publish the MPI according to the original 2010 methodology. For more details regarding the changes made, visit the MPI FAQ: http://hdr.undp.org/en/faq-page/multidimensional-poverty-index-mpi.    Estimates are mostly based on publicly available data and cover various years between 2005 and 2015, which limits cross-country comparability. The MPI methodology also uses expert judgment to fill in missing data, which can bias the results.    The MPI can tentatively be used to measure changes in poverty over time provided that data are available from the same survey at different years. Users are advised to investigate the data input to these multiple surveys, as different sets of data may be missing in the different surveys.', 'function': 'Summarizes information on the multidimensional experience of poverty into a single number, considering health, education, and standard of living indicators.', 'technical_title': 'Multi-dimension Poverty Index (MPI)', 'source_organization': 'United Nations Development Programme (UNDP)/Oxford Poverty and Human Development Initiative (OPHI)', 'name': 'Multidimentional Poverty Index', 'data_type': 'Vector', 'wri_rw_id': 'soc.006'}, 'createdAt': '2017-08-28T14:24:42.291Z', 'updatedAt': '2017-10-10T20:14:59.139Z', 'status': 'published'}}]

[{'id': '59a427a7ce86740012fcb22d', 'type': 'metadata', 'attributes': {'dataset': '24f9654b-c542-4987-a6fc-7d5b6339e3c4', 'application': 'rw', 'resource': {'type': 'dataset', 'id': '24f9654b-c542-4987-a6fc-7d5b6339e3c4'}, 'language': 'en', 'name': 'Human Development Index', 'description': 'The Human Development Index (HDI) is a summary measure of average achievement in key dimensions of human development: a long and healthy life, being knowledgeable, and a decent standard of living. The HDI is the geometric mean of normalized indices for each of the 3 dimensions. The health dimension is assessed by life expectancy at birth; the education dimension is measured by mean of years of schooling for adults aged 25 years and more and expected years of schooling for children of school-entering age. The standard of living dimension is measured by gross national income per capita. The HDI uses the logarithm of income to reflect the diminishing importance of income with increasing gross national income (GNI). The scores for the 3 HDI dimension indices are then aggregated into a composite index using geometric mean. The HDI is calculated for 188 countries annually. For additional information, please see http://hdr.undp.org/sites/default/files/hdr2015_technical_notes.pdf.', 'source': 'UNDP', 'info': {'data_download_original_link': 'http://hdr.undp.org/en/data#', 'data_download_link': 'https://wri-public-data.s3.amazonaws.com/resourcewatch/soc_004_human_development_index.zip', 'learn_more_link': 'http://hdr.undp.org/en/indicators/137506', 'frequency_of_updates': 'Annual', 'date_of_content': '1980-2015', 'spatial_resolution': 'National', 'geographic_coverage': 'Developing countries', 'link_to_license': 'https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/igo/', 'summary_of_license': 'Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 IGO', 'citation': 'United Nations Development Programme, Human Development Report. 1980-2015. "Human Development Index." Retrieved from http://hdr.undp.org/en/composite/HDI. Accessed through Resource Watch, [date]. www.resourcewatch.org.', 'cautions': 'The HDI simplifies and captures only part of what human development entails. It does not reflect on inequalities, poverty, human security, empowerment, etc.', 'function': 'A composite index measuring average achievement in 3 basic dimensions of human development: a long and healthy life, knowledge, and a decent standard of living.', 'technical_title': None, 'source_organization': 'United Nations Development Programme (UNDP)', 'name': 'Human Development Index', 'data_type': 'Tabular', 'wri_rw_id': 'soc.004'}, 'createdAt': '2017-08-28T14:24:39.635Z', 'updatedAt': '2017-10-10T20:14:58.739Z', 'status': 'published'}}]
